The '''Berlin Airlift Device'''<ref>Army Regulation 600-8-22, Dec. 11, 2006, P. 75, 6--11.</ref> is miniature gold airplane<ref>DoD Manual 1348.33 V3, P. 1 (2), "service devices"</ref> that was awarded for wear on occupation medals and ribbons issued to [[United States Army]], [[Navy]], [[Marine Corps]], and [[Coast Guard]] service personnel for participation in or in direct support of, the [[Berlin airlift]] during the [[Cold War]].<ref>Army Regulation 600-8-22, Dec. 11, 2006, Army of Occupation Medal, P. 66, 5--11, a. (3).</ref>
==History== The Berlin Airlift Device is awarded for service of 92 consecutive days with a unit credited with participation in the Berlin airlift, or by competent field authority on an individual basis within the period June 26, 1948 to September 30, 1949 inclusive. U.S. Army orders announcing award of the Berlin Airlift device will specifically award the [[Army of Occupation Medal]] to persons otherwise not eligible therefor.<ref>Army Regulation 600-8-22, Dec. 11, 2006, (Army of Occupation Medal) P. 67, 5--11, (8) b. (2).</ref> The device is a gold colored metal miniature of a [[Douglas C-54]] cargo airplane. It is worn centered on the suspension and [[service ribbon]] of the Army of Occupation Medal or [[Navy Occupation Service Medal]]. When worn on the suspension ribbon, the device is pinned beneath the ''Germany'' [[Medal bar|medal clasp]].
Those awarded the Army of Occupation Medal or Navy Occupation Service Medal and the Berlin Airlift Device may also be entitled to the [[Medal for Humane Action]]<ref>Army Regulation, 600-8-22, Dec. 12, 2006, P. 66, 5--10.</ref> awarded for at least 120 days of service or direct support thereof of the Berlin airlift. The 31 American service personnel and one Army civilian worker of the 101 persons who lost their lives mostly due to plane crashes during the Berlin airlift were awarded the Medal of Humane Action posthumously.
